item.title: 223: Classic Nutrient Timing Research – Is the Debate Dead?
item.description: Ahh, nutrient timing – such a controversial topic these days – but does it have to be? In today’s episode we revisit a classic nutrient timing study and discuss what makes a good study, how people latch on to their own research, and what makes a good study. John always reviews the full-text of each study review on the show, but to see the abstract please go to: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17095924 . This podcast is proudly sponsored by John’s premium exercise equipment and apparel company Barbell 1. Check out http://barbell1.com for helpful tutorial videos on training and nutrition and the Barbell 1 product line.

item.title: 222: James Tatum and Travis Cooper - Olympic Weightlifting National Champions - Pt 1
item.description: James Tatum and Travis Cooper are both members of team Muscle Driver USA, a team of elite weightlifters based in the Carolinas. I watched these guys take first and second in the 77 kilo weight class at the 2014 USAW Weightlifting National Championships held in Salt Lake City Utah just this July. With these placings, both are strong candidates to represent the USA in weightlifting at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio. As for previous placings, I could go on all day, both have won gold and silver medals at previous American and national championships as well. While their accomplishments on the platform are more than reason to have them on the show, what’s particularly interesting about James and Travis is they also host a podcast called the weightlifting scoop and in my opinion have conducted some of the most interesting self-experiments I’ve heard of in recent years in relation to training. We discuss these experiments and much more in part 1 of this 2 part interview.

item.description: So many powerlifters and bodybuilders are pulling sumo these days compared to the old school conventional deadlift, but is this necessarily better or does it depend? Today’s research article compares the two styles of deadlifting across many aspects and the discussion half of the episode is all about the pros and cons of so many bodybuilders gravitating to powerlifting these days. item.description: The popularity of the deadlift is rapidly increasing with the rise of crossfit and more people trying out powerlifting, but what about the trap or hex bar deadlift. Today’s research study compares performance and motion difference between the conventional and hex bar deadlift variations and leads to discussion on potential applications of each variant in programming. item.title: 215: No Carbs after 6 PM? AND Who Determines Your Self Worth?
item.description: So many people warn don’t eat carbs after 6 PM or don’t eat at all too close to bed – supposedly you’ll gain fat much easier, but is that really true? Today’s research study reviewed actually shows some benefits to eating late. The discussion half of the episode focuses a lot on relativity, in relation to meal timing, training timing, and frequency, and even self-concept and confidence – so much is relative and John shares why he thinks so many people view things too absolute. John always reviews the full-text of each study review on the show, but to see the abstract please go to: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23768612 This podcast is proudly sponsored by John’s premium exercise equipment and apparel company Barbell 1. item.title: 214: How Does Your Body Fight you from Losing Weight?
item.description: Metabolic damage, metabolic adaptation, reverse dieting, and refeeds are all largely buzz or pop words known mostly to the bodybuilding and fitness community and are less familiar to other groups. But is there science to back these words up? Today’s episode looks at a nicely done research review that highlights a variety of reasons that explain these phenomena observed by leading nutrition practitioners and includes the best available recommendations of how to keep a healthy metabolism during advanced dieting in lean active individuals. The second half of the episode includes by reflections on my own personal experience and additional thinking on explaining what goes on with our bodies and how to know if you’re cut out to prepare athletes for bodybuilding and physique competitions, I don’t believe it’s for everyone even if they possess much of the necessary knowledge. John always reviews the full-text of each study review on the show, but to see the abstract please go to: http://www.jissn.com/content/pdf/1550-2783-11-7.pdf This podcast is proudly sponsored by John’s premium exercise equipment and apparel company Barbell 1. Check out http://barbell1.com for helpful tutorial videos on training and nutrition and the Barbell 1 product line.

item.title: 213: How Much Heavier Can You Go with Negative Reps?
item.description:
We’ve all heard that the body can handle more weight eccentrically or through the lowering motion in resistance training compared to the concentric or lifting part. However, little is know about how much more and how to properly program for it. Thus, today’s research study generates a linear equation to help predict eccentric training loads. The discussion half of the episode is all about practical in the trenches tips and pointers on eccentric training from yours truly – personal experience revealed! John always reviews the full-text of each study review on the show, but to see the abstract please go to: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24235981

This podcast is proudly sponsored by John’s premium exercise equipment and apparel company Barbell 1. Check out http://barbell1.com for helpful tutorial videos on training and nutrition and the Barbell 1 product line.

item.title: 212: Bosse Gets Real – Quitting Day Job, Finding Passion, Building Confidence
item.description: Host John Bosse shares the story of quitting his "day job" in May of 2014 and discusses that despite the success of his podcast, he experiences many of the same doubts and reservations as everyone else when making this kind of transition. John shares things he's tried in effort to avoid the inevitable, owning his love for product creation and becoming proud of selling his products. He hopes you'll find some inspiration in hearing his story and realizing he's no different than you and shares many of the same fears and doubts, but presses on!

item.title: 211: Does a Cardio Warm-Up Before Weights Influence Muscle Soreness?
item.description: With the increased popularity of weight training it seems many resistance training athletes are arriving at the gym and training immediately and neglecting traditional low intensity cardio before and after the weights as warm up and cool down. Is this OK or is it more optimal to warm[up and cool down? Today’s research study looks at this issue and leads to a discussion half of the episode all about weighting of time to training vs. pre and post-training routines and what may be some perks of particular strategies. John always reviews the full-text of each study review on the show, but to see the abstract please go to: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23486850

item.title: 210: Bodybuilding Contest Prep – Is Yours Based on Science?
item.description: While many natural bodybuilders like to consider their practices in contest preparation more advanced than many of the tactics employed in untested federations where performance enhancing drug regimens can increase the odds of a greater variety of contest peaking strategies, there still is little research on bodybuilders. After many listeners requests, today John reviews a recent comprehensive research review article relating to how to optimize contest preparation for natural bodybuilding. John always reviews the full-text of each study review on the show, but to see the abstract please go to: http://www.jissn.com/content/pdf/1550-2783-11-20.pdf

item.title: 209: Does Eccentric Lifting Activate Leg Muscles vs. Concentric?
item.description: Most of us hear about the possible greater gains in muscle size and strength with eccentric training, but how universal is this style of training and what is the reason for these potentially better gains. The study reviewed on today’s show points to greater muscle activation of the quads with eccentric training likely due to heavier loads lifted as compared to concentric training. The discussion half of the episode is about practical applications of eccentric training. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.johk.pl/files/10078-41-2014-v41-2014-01.pdf

item.title: 208: Squat Depth – How to Get it With Slight Knee Pain
item.description: So many high level athletes, bodybuilders, and powerlifters experience pain in the front of the knee at some point during their training life. Today’s research study examined possible taping techniques to alleviate some of this pain and leads to further discussion on safely achieving optimal range of motion, movement patterns, and injury prevention though paying attention to various details on all of the above. Much of the perspective shared related to John’s personal lifelong battle with patellar tendonitis. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.johk.pl/files/23clifford.pdf

item.title: Cardio BEFORE Weights for Optimal Anabolic Response, Say What?!?!
item.description: While people still debate if cardio or resistance training should be done first, I’d say most bodybuilders and powerlifters would opt for cardio last to prioritize weight training, but what if doing so was sabotaging the anabolic response and they didn’t even know it? Today’s research study reviewed raises this question and leads to applications discussion on how to combine these two types of training optimally for prioritizing muscle and strength gains. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25028991

item.title: 205: Is Strongman Training Good For Size and Strength?
item.description: Training with strongman implements is gaining great popularity for general fitness and for traditional athletes. But what about the typical gym athlete like a bodybuilder or powerlifter? Would they see any benefit to training strongman style. Today’s episode reviews a research article examining the carryover of strongman training to the size and strength gains powerlifters and bodybuilders are after. The applications half of the episode is all about being less judgemental in choosing training and nutrition programs and thinking deeper about what is going to produce the results you desire best, FOR YOU. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://mobile.journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/_layouts/oaks.journals.mobile/articleviewer.aspx?year=9000&issue=00000&article=97264

item.description: Arnold and old school bodybuilders used to talk about lifting in the morning for better testosterone response and this belief is still held by many. Does it matter if you lift in the morning or afternoon? Today’s research study examines this. Today’s discussion half of the episode is about normal daily habits that we may not appreciate which could be influencing our testosterone levels. item.title: 203: Tyler Mayer & Paul Revelia Pt 2 - Vary Training, Surround Yourself w/Positive Pt 2
item.description:
Paul Revelia and Tyler Mayer are both highly sought after contest prep coaches for bodybuilding, physique, figure, and bikini competitors. Both have helped numerous athletes earn professional status in these sports. Both are pro natural bodybuilders and both have competed multiple times in drug free powerlifting posting some impressive numbers on the platform. Both are sponsored athletes and reps with Core Nutritionals. My main motive for having these two guests on in tandem is they share many similarities in their approaches, background, and future goals, yet each offer a unique perspective, a slightly different story, and slightly different methods. Tyler is the owner of Team TNT and Paul is the owner of Pro Physique.com.

Part 2 of the interview focuses on balancing powerlifting and bodybuilding as well as more on chasing the fitness dream of pursuing a meaningful career you're passionate about.

item.description: With all the talk about anecdotal, but convincing metabolic damage case studies being shared all over the internet it’s important to look for hard scientific data as in today’s study on irregular menstrual function and attempts to restore it by eating more. item.title: 200: Does type of Dairy Protein Powder Matter?
item.description: The debate on whey or fast milk proteins vs. the slow digesting milk protein casein still exist likely due to years of conflicting data on the long term efficacy of either – both appear to have benefits. Today’s research study compared milk protein isolate to casein protein on reistance training gains over a 10 week training program and the reporting o the results leads to the applications half of the episode being about industry bias in supplementation studies. item.title: 198: Fully Customizable Oatmeal & Peanut Butter - Anthony Collova of MyOatmeal.com Pt 2
item.description: Anthony Collova is the mastermind behind My Oatmeal.com and also an amateur bodybuilder. My Oatmeal.com allows you to create your own custom blend of oats with a variety of mix ins – you can even customize the flavors in creating your own low fat peanut butter powder called PB Lean. Being someone who makes custom exercise equipment I am always intrigued by other business owners who take a grassroots approach and offer their customers full customization as Anthony and his girlfriend do. He joins me on the show and answers a lot of tough business questions that you’re sure to get a lot out of as you get your fitness business started and decide how to scale up or keep things under one roof. Anthony's story is very inspirational having had previous problems with drug abuse and owning previous businesses that he was less passionate about. Hearing how he overcame all of this and has gotten to his current state of success is content you won't want to miss! If you missed part 1 of this interview be sure to catch episode 194!

item.title: 192: “Clean” and “Dirty” Carbs – Fact or Myth?
item.description: Nutrition professionals and trainers argue back and forth on the importance or whole grains or the reality of flexible dieting when done correctly – it can incorporate refined grains and good results can still be obtained. Both sides make fair points and can find data to support their recommendations. Today’s show reviews a study directly comparing whole vs. refined grains and looks for differential effects on weight loss and body composition. This leads to further pros and cons discussion of consuming diets higher in either. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/early/2014/06/18/ajcn.113.078048.abstract
item.itunes:subtitle: Nutrition professionals and trainers argue back and forth on the importance or whole grains or the reality of flexible dieting when done correctly – it can incorporate refined grains and good results can still be obtained. Both sides make fair...

item.title: 191: What to do When Your Gym Doesn’t Have Machines you Want?
item.description: The study reviewed on today’s show is on pre-exercise use of a vibration platform to improve upper body power. Recognizing that many do not have access to a vibration platform today’s episode was inspired to have an applications discussion relating to improvising with existing equipment to created exercises mimicking machines some may not have at their gym, thus allowing the listener to get more out of their current equipment. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24838267

item.title: 190: Do White and Black People Burn Different Amounts of Calories?
item.description: We often express disappointment that there is not more research on women to determine if they respond different to training and nutrition interventions as compared to men. But how about blacks vs. whites – does anyone ever consider this factor? If not, are there ethnic differences? Today’s research study examines this topic and also leads to discussion on the use of technology and devices to track progress – should we really hang our hat on the numbers? John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24816887
item.itunes:subtitle: We often express disappointment that there is not more research on women to determine if they respond different to training and nutrition interventions as compared to men. But how about blacks vs. whites – does anyone ever consider this factor?...

item.description: If you're like John and couldn't make it to the 2014 National Strength and Conditioning Association's national conference this past week in Las Vegas, you are in luck. Eric Trexler, CSCS returns as guest host of today's show and provides a valuable recap of some of the event's top presentations from the leading researchers on the latest developments in the areas of sports nutrition, supplementation, and most of all: training for strength and muscle size. You won't want to miss the episode - thank you Eric for sharing with us!

item.title: 188: How Important is Bar Speed?
item.description: We always hear mixed advice on how fast to do our reps in the gym, some go super slow, some in between, and others fast and explosive. The study I’m reviewing today looked to dive into what’s most optimal further. The discussion half of the episode follows breaking down important details of smith machine training and further discussion of the high variability in response to training and possible predisposing factors. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24886926

item.title: 187: Does Ethnicity Dictate the Optimal Training Program?
item.description: We all here people say in slang passing comments – oh it’s because he’s black. In this way referring to black athletes outperforming whites due to a genetic advantage the whites supposedly cannot overcome. Meanwhile a more balanced approach would likely view this ethnic discrepancy as there’s likely to be scenarios where whites outperform and then other scenarios where blacks outperform. The discussion half of today’s episode relates to broadening the ethnicity of one’s clientele and learning from others who have previously worked with a more diverse clientele than yourself. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24577858

item.title: 186: How Common Are Serious & Overuse Injuries in Competitive Bodybuilding?
item.description: There’s been a fair amount of research done on injury rates in sports that revolve around lifting weights, but little on bodybuilding despite all the anecdotal stuff that floats around. Today we review a research study on the topic of bodybuilding injury rates among the highest levels of competitors. Meanwhile, the discussion that follows centers around finding a balanced perspective on how much to push though pain and how much weight to put on competitive success in bodybuilding. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24886919

item.description: Reverse pec deck machines have two different hand positions and you see people using both, but which is best according to research? Today John reviews a research article on this comparison and discusses the importance of recognizing large variations among people in how they “feel” target muscles during their exercises. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23302754

item.title: 184: Should you Do General Warm-Up Before Warm-Up Sets?
item.description: There’s still a good amount of people who do light cardio as a general warm-up before their warm-up sets and hitting the weights, but increasingly I see more and more people skip this and go right to the weights. I’ve always felt this was suboptimal, yet those individuals always seemed to know what they were doing and would tell me I was wasting my energy. But is there any scientific data to guide this decision on optimal warm-up? Thankfully today’s study compares no general warm-up to general warm-ups of varying intensity and duration leading to some solid discussion on all the above. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22692116

item.title: 183: Best Grip Width for Upright Rows? – Wide or Narrow?
item.description: I don’t feel like I see as many people doing upright rows in the gym as I used to and those that I do are usually using a narrow grip, but is there any research to support a certain grip width over another? Today’s study reviewed compares 3 different grips widths and their effects on trap and delt activation in the upright row exercise. The applications half of the episode is about exercise selection and spacing within training splits, and also muscle length change vs. extent of activation and any possible role that may play in differential muscle hypertrophy. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22362088

item.description: Stay tuned till the end for an idea that could help with the ankle mobility so many of us lack! Despite a solid amount of researcher cautioning athletes and strength coaches against pre-exercise static stretching because it may hurt their performance, it’s still very common at all levels of sport. Some data raises alarm and some does not – but why? Today’s research study tries to hone in on an optimal stretch duration and also if how elite one is influences their ability to see benefits. The applications half of the episode focuses on trying to come to an optimal stretching protocol. item.title: 181: Next Gen Fat Loss – Sleeping Oxygen Deprived
item.description: You’ve heard me talk about low-oxygen training on the show a couple times before – but how about low oxygen sleeping? We know elite athletes like Michael Phelps do it – but what applications does it have for ordinary people? Today we touch upon some pilot data which seems to indicate low-oxygen sleeping may significantly increase body-fat loss when added to diet and exercise. The applications discussion talks about getting creative to see results with individuals that are not responding to or complying with traditional approaches to body composition optimization. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24962246

item.title: 180: Jeff Alberts Top Lightweight Pro Natural Bodybuilder: It Doesn’t Have to Be Complicated and You Can Have Life Balance!
item.description: Today’s interview with top lightweight natural pro bodybuilder Jeff Alberts is all about keeping it simple. We discuss a lot of detail on this podcast and I think it’s important at times to step back and recognize the basics and I think you will find today’s episode particularly inspiring to see someone with as impressive a physique as Jeff share just how simple his training and nutrition programming is. Jeff is a great example of someone in tune with his body and the bigger meaning of life – which is so much more important than this gym hobby we all have. Jeff also shares some unique perspectives on client/coach relationships that were new to me. Enjoy!

item.title: 179: How Common are Injuries in CrossFit?
item.description: With the explosion of CrossFit these days there has been a backlash of people swearing up and down that it leads to lots of injuries and has people who are not yet fit enough to be doing its movememnts jumping head first into training sure to lead to injury. Still others say even if that were true that’s a lot better than all the people who are getting started sitting around and being inactive. Is there any research to show that either camp is right? We review a study on the frequency of Crossfit injuries today and hope to get to the bottom of this debate. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24276294

item.title: 178: Citrulline Malate Supplementation - Worth it or Hype? w/Guest Host Eric Trexler
item.description: Citrulline and citrulline malate are common  ingredients in many pre-workout supplements. As they have become mainstays it almost seems universally accepted that they produce pretty impressive results. Today, guest host Eric Trexler, BS, CSCS, CISSN takes a more critical look at the current data available on these ingredients and makes suggestions for contexts in which they may and may not be worth it. Thank you for the great content Eric!

item.description: If your goal for resistance training is not just purely getting big and strong, but also to burn calories and fat to shape your body, what are good exercises to choose? Could you even do some stuff in place of cardio? Today’s research study compares moves traditional to Crossfit along with large muscle mass recruiting and smaller muscle mass recruiting resistance training exercises to compare energy expenditure across them and get us answers. The applications half of the episode contains further thinking on how to maximize resistance training energy expenditure practically. item.title: 175: Shaping a Muscle – Is it Possible?
item.description: Can you really target your “lower” or “upper portion of a muscle that runs lengthwise on your body? There’s only outer and inner muscle heads so this upper lower stuff must just be broscience, right? Well, perhaps not really – today’s research study shows this through a study comparing upper and lower hamstrings muscle activation during two different styles of exercises. This leads to some interesting applications discussion on exercise selection in program design. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Abstract/publishahead/Regional_Differences_in_Muscle_Activation_During.97305.aspx

item.title: 174: Is Fructose so Bad if You Workout Regularly?
item.description: So many people talk about how bad fructose is for us these days while still others say we need lots of fruit to be healthy – but fruit is high in fructose. Is all the scare relevant for both overweight and normal weight people or if you exercise does that lower your risk for any bad effects? These questions are touched upon in both today’s research study reviewed as well as the commentary that follows the review. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here:  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24848492

item.description: Several years ago it seemed like everyone recommended 5 or 6 small meals a day and now it seems there’s been a backlash whereby more flexible dieting principles have tried to instill that meal frequency does not matter, but are they oversimplifying things? Today’s research study reviewed looks at meal frequency and level of protein intake and their roles in body composition optimization. The applications half of the episode attempts to put all of the above in context for real world implementation. Today we look at a study a glutamine supplementation and any role it may play in recovery from working out. This leads to discussion on guarding against jumping on bandwagons when recommending supplements and also in not ruling out efficacy of supplements too soon. item.title: 169: Does Post-Workout Protein Spacing Matter?
item.description: Some people practically have protein on a constant drip into their bodies, while others are feast or famine style. Then probably more people in the fitness world advocate a more steady fairly often intake of protein. Which is best and is there research that points one way or another? Should you have the same amount of protein at each meal or should it fluctuate? Science and theory on all the above are discussed in today’s episode as inspired by the research study reviewed. item.title: 165: Best of MSA - Book Smart,Gym Smart, or Both? Cliff Wilson Interview Pt 2! - Ep 34 Re-Air
item.description:
We’re back with part 2 of the interview with Cliff Wilson. In part one, Episode 22, Cliff shared interesting theory on the contradiction whereby some of his clients with the slowest metabolisms can get the leanest, yet some of his clients with crazy high metabolisms struggle to reach elite levels of body composition. Part 2 covers the conflict between formally educated trainers/coaches vs. those without formal education and how to balance use of both knowledge sets for those possessing both. If you’re a client looking for a coach or trainer – John and Cliff also share how to find the best coach or trainer for you! Additional insights are shared on carving out your methods as a professional and staying adaptable in them. Calories in v. calories out doesn’t necessarily equal weight gain or loss – and the nuances of why this might be so are discussed. Finally, did you know Cliff used to play basketball against the NBA’s in high school? Be sure to listen through for those stories and more!
Note: Cliff was pivotal to my first season success as a natural bodybuilder. I was blown away by the transformation to my physique while under his guidance in such a short period of time. I give his services my highest recommendation!

item.title: 164: Best of MSA - Cliff Wilson on Fat Loss Rate vs. Fat Loss Potential - Ep 23 Re-Air
item.description:
Cliff Wilson is one of the most sought after natural bodybuilding contest prep coaches and one of the brightest minds in the industry. He and his wife Katie, as Team Wilson, have worked with several hundred successful clients and in 2013 alone helped 12 natural bodybuilders and physique competitors earn professional status in their sport! These 12 are some of 30 athletes Cliff and Katie have helped turn pro!
Today Cliff shares a very compelling theory on the difference of how fast one loses body fat when dieting compared to the total amount of body fat they are able to lose even at a very slow rate. As with any incredibly insightful person like Cliff, this interview quickly dovetails into pure gold as Cliff drops all kinds of valuable insight on many topics relating to training and nutrition. So much, that this is just part 1 - stay tuned for part 2 of this interview in a few weeks!
Note: Cliff was pivotal to my first season success as a natural bodybuilder. I was blown away by the transformation to my physique while under his guidance in such a short period of time. I give his services my highest recommendation!

item.title: 162: What’s Backward Periodization and How Does it Compare?
item.description: Everyone always talked about linear and non-linear periodization or even daily undulating periodization. The former usually moves from lighter heavier weights, but if someone is already well trained does it have to go in this order? What about going from heavier to lighter weights – what effects does that have? We do a throwback Thursday episode today looking at a 2009 study on reverse linear periodization. The applications half of today’s episode focuses on specific related thoughts on program design and also touches on detraining and non-uniform gains across different measures in our programs and how to wrap our heads around this phenomenon. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19057409  If you enjoy this podcast you’ll love the MUSCLE Detailz tribe – more info at http://appliedmusclescience.com/detailz

item.title: 160: Best of MSA Dr. Layne Norton a Behind the Scenes Look Episode 36 Re-Air
item.description:
Holding a PhD in Nutritional Sciences, multiple natural bodybuilding pro cards, and elite status as a raw powerlifter – Layne Norton is a leader in the field of body composition optimization. Check the end of these show notes for more info on how to find all of Layne’s great content, but today it’s all about the behind the scenes stuff:
- Of all the things Layne’s involved in what does he enjoy the most? How about the least?
- What is a typical day like for Layne? How does he balance family and business with the bodybuilding and fitness lifestyle?
- How is Layne training and eating currently? Using himself as an example he also speaks about the importance of letting your methods evolve as you learn and develop as an athlete.
- When will we see him on a powerlifting platform next? Is he considering stepping on the bodybuilding stage again anytime soon?
- Does Layne have other superstitions or habits to enhance his training and workouts?
- The laws of calories in vs. calories out defied by improper exercise and nutrition habits – evidence from 100s of clients
- Expanding the BioLayne Team after the Metabolic Damage video series, the art of client referral
- Who are the people working behind the scenes with Layne and what do they do?
- If he can find time – what does Layne do outside of training and nutrition for enjoyment?
- What are the next big things in store for Layne and his team?
- What are some opportunities he’s passed up over the years? His thoughts on staying independent rather than employed.
- Layne and John Otis Hollywood
- The TRUTH about the amount of work it takes to achieve Layne’s level of success
- If he had to choose Bucs or Colts for football which would it be?
Some of my favorite educational videos from Dr. Layne Norton
Metabolic Damage http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QHHzie6XRGk
Metabolic Capacity http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EY1DsZMNfNw
Reverse Dieting http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A3gTGLulLnI
Find more great content at http://biolayne.com!

item.title: 159: Low Oxygen Training – Boosts or Hurts Gains?
item.description: It seems like there’s so many unique ways to make weight training harder these days. One of these ways is via exposing the body to low oxygen levels while working out through either wearing a mask or working out in a room set to be low in oxygen. But wouldn’t this kind of workout restrict your gains because you wouldn’t be able to train as hard? Today’s research study looks at this topic and tries to determine if there are any “extra” gains to be obtained from training under low oxygen. This study provokes discussion about weighing whether or not to add a new method to your training program vs. sticking with what’s worked in the past and also brainstorms future areas to test around hypoxic training. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24907297  If you enjoy this podcast you’ll love the MUSCLE Detailz tribe – more info at http://appliedmusclescience.com/detailz

item.title: 158: Can Excess Protein Calories Make You Leaner?
item.description: Some people say a calorie is a calorie is a calorie. While still others say that protein calories are less of a concern for getting fat when consumed in excess. Today’s research study provides participants with excess calories from protein and fat as sees what happen over 4 weeks. Review of this study leads to the second half of the episode being a brief discussion on what makes for a meaningful comparison of protein intakes in a study. item.title: 157: Leg Curls, Glute-Ham, RDL, or Good Morning for Hamstrings?
item.description: Most everyone does leg curls in the gym, but no so many do RDLs, and even fewer do glute ham raises as often the standard equipment is not even available. But are we missing the boat? What does research tell us about the best way to activate our hamstrings to have the best chance at developing them? Today’s research study compares hamstrings muscle activation during each of the 4 lifts mentioned in the title. The applications half of the episode focuses on the error in making all clients do the same exercises and some thoughts on program design around the hamstrings. item.title: 156: Assuming Same Amino Content all Proteins are Equal?
item.description: Is there ever going to be a newly discovered “magic” protein source or are these claims and such always exaggerated and just hype? What about the people that say free form amino acids are best for building muscle – are they right or way off? Today’s research study reviewed compares whey hydrolysate to free form amino acids post-exercise. The applications half of the episode discusses reductionist thinking in nutrition and how unfortunately supplement industry overhype clouds are from being able to see some true innovations that may still be to come. item.title: 154: Michael Phelps' Strength & Conditioning Coordinator Keenan Robinson Shares Advanced MUSCLE Recovery Techniques - Pt 2 of 2
item.description:
Ever wondered the recovery techniques Michael Phelps uses to be at the top and able to perform as the greatest Olympic athlete of all time consistently? Tune in to Part 2 of this 2 part interview with Phelps' strength & conditioning coordinator Keenan Robinson continued from episode 152. You might be surprised how much overlap there is between strength and conditioning considerations in the swimming world and the powerlifting/bodybuilding world as Keenan and I note. We delve into some advanced recovery modalities applicable to all the above in this episode.
Keenan Robinson is the personal strength and conditioning coordinator for the greatest Olympic athlete of all time, Michael Phelps. Keenan provided cutting edge dryland and overall training programming during Phelps' runs at 22 Olympics medals, 18 Gold, in 2004, 2008, and 2012. Robinson is also the Director of Athletes Services at the North Baltimore Aquatic Club, training numerous other elite swimmers who are current and future Olympic contenders.

item.title: 153: Does Race Influence Our Response to Overeating?
item.description: We often talk about how fat people or skinny people respond to different diets. But how much of it is these factors and how much of it is ethnicity – perhaps we neglect to consider race and ethnicity. Today’s study compares the response to high fat overfeeding in white Europeans as compared to Asians. The study’s content leads to the second half of the episode being a discussion of the postprandial state and duration of meals with speculations to perhaps spur future research. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24506887  If you enjoy this podcast you’ll love the MUSCLE Detailz tribe – more info at http://appliedmusclescience.com/detailz

item.title: 150: Can Sleep Prevent Getting Fat?
item.description: We all know sleep is important, but so many of us put it off in favor of getting more work done or having more fun. But are we shooting our body composition in the foot? Surely not, right, as long as we control our food and activity, right? Not quite. The study reviewed today digs into this topic deeper and the episode ends with applications discussion on the importance of recognizing the simple things that have the biggest effects on our gains and not letting the details cloud us from seeing them. item.title: 142: Does Fat Type Matter for Body Composition?
item.description: With the rise of IIFYM – if it fits your macros or flexible dieting, it seems everyone wants to act like food source and macronutrient source doesn’t matter, but increasingly there are scientific studies and scholarly review papers that say these factors do matter. Who’s right, the people in the field challenging so called “bro science” or the scientists? Or does it depend on the context either is speaking to? John tends to support the latter notion and will explain why as he reviews today’s study and discusses related applications tips and considerations. item.title: 140: MTV True Life I Want the Perfect Body's Anthony Monetti - Pt 2
item.description:
Anthony Monetti from MTV’s True Life I Want the Perfect Body in 2003 is today’s special guest in part 2 of a two part interview. Part 1 was episode 138. Anthony shares the creative ways in which he got himself on TV multiple times. Tells us more about his upcoming projects and gives lots of great insight on balancing an active career of a fitness professional with the challenge of being a professional natural bodybuilder. He also talks about choosing your ideal client that you wish to work with and about his decision to open a Diet Doc Franchise with his gym. We also run through a series of either or questions on training, nutrition, and other areas of life – entertaining and lets you get to know Anthony better.

Anthony Monetti is an accomplished WNBF Professional Natural Bodybuilder having taken 2nd place in the WNBF Pro Universe in 2010 and winning the heavyweights at the 2013 WNBF Pro US Cup. Many people know him from his 2003 appearance on MTV’s True Life I Want the Perfect Body Series which documented his journey in trying to turn professional as a natural bodybuilder. Since that time in addition to the turning pro and the placings I just mentioned Anthony’s appeared on the TV show Change of Heart, Change of Heart, represented a video game at Comicon in 2008, been on The NewlyWed Game with your Wife Karen, opened a Diet Doc franchise, promoted natural bodybuilding shows, and opened his own gym bodhi by Anthony Monetti.

item.title: 138: Anthony Monetti - WNBF Pro Bodybuilder & MTV True Life Star - Pt 1
item.description:
Anthony Monetti from MTV’s True Life I Want the Perfect Body in 2003 is today’s special guest in part 1 of a two part interview. He shares the trials and tribulations along the way in achieving that appearance. This is an episode about inspiration to go all in and do what you love and make your dreams as a fitness entrepreneur and competitor come true. Anthony went on to become a professional natural bodybuilder and offers insight on how to give it everything you have yet have strategy and a game plan for a balanced life and life beyond competition. We also discuss how to deal with people doubting your dreams. Anthony is known for being incredibly confident and so he discusses how he stays this way even despite the inevitable failures that come with pushing the limits. Finally, hear more about Anthony’s career as a fitness professional and the inspiring story of starting his gym and providing meals for he and his now wife’s clients. We close this part 1 with Anthony’s advice on using goal setting and a vision board for success.

item.title: 134: Overeating Candy or Peanuts – Is Fat Gain Different?
item.description: A calorie is a calorie right? So if one person gorged on nuts and another gorged on candy they both should get equally fat and have negative metabolic effects, right? Well, maybe it’s not that simple and the study reviewed today gives some clues on why. The applications half of the episode is all about thinking on the bigger picture as to why certain things may or may not cause us to get fatter. John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19396658.  If you enjoyed today’s episode be sure to check out all the additional video content and more at http://appliedmusclescience.com/detailz

item.title: 132: Muscle Protein Synthesis – How Does Weight Loss Effect It? Is there a Dietary Protein “ceiling?”
item.description:
We all inherently know that dieting can be risky business for an athlete’s muscle mass. But what about if they consume more protein? Is there a ceiling on how much protein is beneficial and does that differ if a person is maintaining or trying to lose weight? Today’s episode is jam packed with reviewing research and discussing application tips on this topic. item.title: 131: No Bullsh** Bodybuilding's Ian McCarthy Balances Exercise and Nutrition Science & Application Pt 1
item.description:
If you're at all familiar with the online bodybuilding community you've no doubt heard of Ian McCarthy. Ian has made waves as the incredibly intelligent young guy who stands for science and reason and doesn't stand for bullsh** - openly standing up to industry titans who spew endless "bro science" without sound reasoning to back their methodologies. This outspoken personality has garnered plenty of supporters and a fair share of haters. Ian joins the show today to share a solid balance of the science and application that is behind his recommended methods.

Ian McCarthy is the founder of Lifting for Life and most notably No Bullshit Bodybuilding – both online fitness communities with fast growing followings. Ian’s Lifting for Life YouTube channel is approaching 25,000 subscribers and his No Bullshit Bodybuilding page has over 80,000 fans. Originally from France, Ian now lives in the United States. Despite only being 21, I consider him to be very well spoken and knowledgeable on many areas related to health, nutrition, and exercise science both from a great deal of self-study and first hand experience including recovering from a battle with anorexia. Clearly other veterans in the field recognize his expertise as well as he has appeared as a guest on other popular shows including RX Muscle’s Heavy Muscle Radio and has hosted roundtable nutrition discussions with leading professionals such as Alan Aragon and Eric Helms.

item.title: 130: High Protein Diets – Just How High Can you Go?
item.description:
So many “experts” swear up and down that crazy high protein intakes are not necessary. Yet there still always plenty of “meatheads” who’ve been lifting for years that hold to their intakes which are much higher than even most Sports Nutrition authorities would recommend. Who’s right? Does it depend? Is there even any scientific research on this? Today John reviews a study looking at protein intake as high as 4.4 grams per kilogram of bodymass or 2 grams per pound. This leads to some interesting philosophical discussion on protein and extremes in anything relating to the resistance training world.  John always reviews the full text of every article, but to see the abstract of the study discussed, click here: http://www.jissn.com/content/pdf/1550-2783-11-19.pdf  The other review articles John wrote on protein and mentioned in the applications half of today’s episode can be found here:

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12909668

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15914508

If you enjoyed today’s episode be sure to check out all the additional video content and more at http://muscledetails.com
